I see. In that case, let's update the `FigureCanvasTkAgg`'s `figure` property with the newly generated plot each time the `update_graph` function is called. Here's the updated `update_graph` function that does this:
```python
def update_graph(*args, fig=fig):
    fig.clf()
    graph_type = graph_type_var.get()
    if graph_type == "pairplot":
        pair_grid = sns.pairplot(df, hue='Dataset', kind='reg')
        canvas_widget.figure = pair_grid.fig
    elif graph_type == "histogram":
        ax = fig.add_subplot(111)
        sns.histplot(data=df, x="Age", hue="Dataset", kde=True, ax=ax)
        canvas_widget.figure = fig
    elif graph_type == "boxplot":
        ax = fig.add_subplot(111)
        sns.boxplot(data=df, x="Dataset", y="Total_Bilirubin", ax=ax)
        canvas_widget.figure = fig
    canvas_widget.draw_idle()
```
Notice how we create a new `ax` object when generating a histogram or a boxplot and add it to the `fig`. Then, we set the `figure` property of the `FigureCanvasTkAgg` to the `fig` object for all three cases. Finally, we call the `draw_idle` method of the `FigureCanvasTkAgg` object to update the plot.
